instruction: What metric was chosen to measure the accuracy of the results in the related study to evaluate the influence of different soil particle sizes on the accuracy of predicted physical and chemical parameters and how far can this metric go?
Output:
The metric chosen to measure the accuracy of the results in the related study was the Root Mean Square Error of Prediction (RMSEP) and the Residual Prediction Intensity Quotient (RPIQ). The RMSEP measures the average difference between the predicted values and the reference values, while the RPIQ measures the ratio of the range of the reference values to the RMSEP. 

The text does not provide information on how far this metric can go.

instruction: How did the different soil particle sizes influence the accuracy of predicted physical and chemical parameters using infrared spectra acquisition in the related study to evaluate the influence of different soil particle sizes on the accuracy of predicted physical and chemical parameters?
Output: The study found that the different soil particle sizes (< 0.100 mm for MIR and < 2 mm for NIR) did not have a significant influence on the accuracy of predicted physical and chemical parameters using infrared spectra acquisition. The accuracy was evaluated based on the root mean square error of prediction (RMSEP) and the ratio of performance to interquartile range (RPIQ) values. The results showed that there were random variations in the RMSEP and RPIQ values for all soil attributes, regardless of the particle size. Additionally, the spectral models built using ball-milled and < 2 mm sieved soil samples did not show large differences in accuracy parameters simultaneously. Therefore, it can be concluded that both particle sizes resulted in spectra models with the same accuracy in predicting soil attributes.
